This is an fMRI study of social cognition/social communication in healthy adults (interns: N=19, mean age 20.55), examining mentalizing and reward networks during message-encoding and recommendation decisions. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task-evoked analyses (threshold p < .005, k = 60) with coordinates and figures (Table 1, Fig. 1), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Participants fall within the 18–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group. The task and reported outcomes clearly map onto social-related constructs (perspective taking/mentalizing, social communication). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study meets several inclusion criteria (fMRI task on social communication, healthy adult sample age 18–41). However, the reported analyses are region-of-interest (individual STS mapping) based: parameter estimates were extracted from predefined measuring points and tested in MP-wise ROI analyses. The paper does not present or describe a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation/statistical map for the healthy group (no whole-brain voxelwise contrasts, tables of coordinates, or unmasked whole-brain results are reported). Because the review requires at least one group-level whole-brain task-evoked map, this study fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults (face perception of angry vs. neutral faces; participants aged 18–33), the paper does not report a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group (e.g., angry>neutral activation). The reported task results are primarily ROI-based (FFA percent signal change) and seed-based psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity maps. Per exclusion criteria, studies that report only seed-based/effective connectivity without an accompanying healthy-group whole-brain task activation map must be excluded. Therefore it fails the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (agency/intentionality attribution using Heider–Simmel–style animations). Sample includes healthy adult participants (n=12, mean age 25.2, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (High>Low and Low>High) analyzed with SPM2 and thresholded at p<0.001 (uncorrected), with reported activation loci (STS, IFG, occipital regions, etc.). The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and reports unmasked healthy-group task activation maps/contrasts. No exclusion criteria are met, so the study should be included.

The study uses task-based fMRI during a social-related task (observation of interpersonal touch) and explicitly investigates social cognition/affective processing. It includes a healthy adult neurotypical (NT) group reported separately (n=21). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task effects and provides mean group contrasts and MNI peak coordinates (referenced in main/supplementary files, e.g., Figure S2 and Table S2), not limited to ROI-only analyses. Thus it meets the meta-analysis criteria for task fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain results.

This is an fMRI study of social decision-making (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (N=20 males, age 21–37). The task is explicitly social (cooperation/trust), and the paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps: one-sample t tests for task phases (placebo session), flexible factorial and paired t tests examining treatment and opponent effects, thresholded at FWE cluster-corrected p<0.05. Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (within-subject design), with whole-brain activation tables and figures. All inclusion criteria are met (task fMRI, healthy adult sample, whole-brain group-level maps). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are provided).

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation/impression formation (social-meaningful and social-irrelevant vs non-social) using task-based BOLD imaging. It includes a healthy young adult group (ages 20–29) within the 18–65 inclusion range, with group-level analyses reported separately for age groups. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (social vs non-social; social-meaningful vs social-irrelevant), conjunctions, corrected cluster results, and peak coordinates—i.e., unmasked whole-brain activation maps rather than ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only analyses. Thus it satisfies the fMRI social task, healthy adult subgroup, and whole-brain evidence criteria; no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=30, mean age 26) that uses a social-related body perception task probing perception and understanding of self and others. The authors report whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task activation analyses (FEAT/FLAME) with thresholded Z-statistic maps and coordinate results for contrasts (e.g., own body > scrambled; same-sex and opposite-sex other bodies) clearly from the healthy/control sample. Analyses include within-group and between-sex comparisons and parametric whole-brain results. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, and fits the review’s constructs (Perception/Understanding of Self and Others). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of prosody perception and production, a form of social communication relevant to perception/understanding of others and empathy. Participants are healthy adults (n=19; ages 18–58). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., “happy‑neutral”, “question‑neutral”) analyzed with random-effects models and FDR/FWE thresholding and provides whole-brain results and coordinate lists and figures. The design is task-based (production and perception) rather than resting-state or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole‑brain task fMRI of social-related processing.

The full text is a review/theoretical article summarizing concepts and prior findings; although the abstract mentions fMRI results, the provided full text contains introductory/review material without methods, participant information, or reported group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for original empirical fMRI data reporting whole-brain healthy-adult task activation maps. Excluded per the criteria for non-empirical papers or studies that do not report whole-brain healthy-group task results.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, ages 18–24) that reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Popular>Notes, Artistic>Notes, Popular>Artistic, Artistic>Popular) with voxelwise and cluster-level correction and coordinate tables. Although the task is aesthetic music appreciation rather than an explicit ToM task, the authors frame and demonstrate involvement of social-related processing (default mode/ToM and cognitive-empathy regions such as arMFC, PCC/PC, TPJ, hippocampus) and present whole-brain results for those contrasts in the healthy sample. Therefore it meets the sample, whole-brain reporting, and social-related processing relevance criteria (perception/understanding of others; cognitive empathy) for inclusion.

This is an fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=24; ages 22–39) that uses a task-evoked paradigm (recall of pictured memorial items cued by captions) and directly investigates social-related constructs (collective memory, social schemas, narrative comprehension, representation of group viewpoints). The authors report group-level whole-brain analyses (surface-based searchlight with TFCE permutation correction) and ROI and whole-brain results linking dmPFC/vmPFC activity to collective/social representations. All inclusion criteria are met (healthy adult sample, task-based fMRI, and reported group-level whole-brain results). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of gestural social communication (charades) in healthy adult participants (n=18, mean age 27.5). The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses: traditional GLM-derived activations (used to define mirror ROIs) and whole-brain between-brain Granger-causality (bbGCM) maps thresholded at corrected significance. The task is clearly social-communication related, participants are within the 18–65 age range, and whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps are reported for the healthy group. It is not limited to ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only results. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Study collected fMRI data in healthy adult participants (n=6, ages ~26), used whole-brain voxelwise encoding models, and reports group-level voxelwise/ cortical-surface results (e.g., category tuning maps, PC projections, statistical tests) rather than only ROI-restricted analyses. Although the paradigm was passive viewing of natural movies rather than an explicit social task, the analyses explicitly quantify and test responses to social-related categories (e.g., social communication, humans, body parts, animals) and report significant group-level effects. The paper provides whole-brain voxelwise evidence of social-relevant category processing in healthy adults and thus meets the review’s inclusion criteria.

The study uses task-based fMRI of a social-related paradigm (Face Matching Task assessing perception of others’ emotional faces). The sample is a healthy adult group (n=10, mean age 25 ±5.3), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM task results (second-level one-sample t-tests; contrasts such as fear>neutral; coordinates and tables provided in Supplementary Material: Table S2, Figures S1–S3), satisfying the requirement for an unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task activation map. The paper also includes ICA results, but whole-brain task-evoked maps are clearly reported, and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, seed-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore it should be INCLUDED.

This is an fMRI study of facial emotion discrimination, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Sample includes healthy adult control group (ages 19–35) reported separately from the excessive smartphone group. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked results (cluster tables with FWE-corrected p-values and >100 voxels) including within-group contrasts for the normal control (NC) group (e.g., NC activations for AH vs HH), not limited to ROI-only analyses. Imaging methods and whole-brain statistical maps/coordinates are described. Age range and healthy control reporting meet inclusion criteria; the study is empirical with original task-based fMRI data. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of deception (a social behavior involving understanding/manipulation of others) using a task-based design in a healthy adult sample (24 males, ages 19–60). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise task contrasts (lie vs truth) with whole-brain statistical maps/cluster results (thresholded maps reported in tables/figures) and also applies small-volume corrections for ROIs. Results for the healthy/control group are presented directly (main effects and correlations). Age range and participant health meet inclusion criteria, and the study is empirical with original task-evoked fMRI data. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, or non-healthy-only samples) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of emotional facial expressions, including affiliation-relevant emotions). The sample comprises 40 healthy adult volunteers and results are reported for the healthy group. The abstract and highlights describe task-evoked brain activation in multiple brain regions (thalamus, temporo-parietal cortex, cerebellum, amygdala, cortical areas), indicating group-level whole-brain task activation rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only results. No clinical-only sample, and the study reports empirical fMRI data during an explicit social task. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria (social fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation reported). Note: full text did not verbatim state ‘voxelwise whole-brain map’ in the abstract, but the reported distributed activations and standard fMRI reporting in the journal Neuroscience support inclusion.

Meets all inclusion criteria: task is social (take-advice game and one-shot trust game probing perception/understanding of others, trustworthiness, social cognition) and conducted during fMRI. Sample: 31 healthy adult participants (mean age 24.3, right-handed, no neurological/psychiatric disorders) within 18–65. Whole-brain group-level task-evoked results are reported (whole-brain univariate contrasts with voxel-level p<0.001 and cluster-level FWE p<0.05; MVPA and searchlight results and coordinate tables/supplementary materials provided). Study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, and reports healthy-group whole-brain effects clearly. Therefore it should be INCLUDED.

Although this is an fMRI study of social cognition (theory of mind) in healthy adult participants, the reported analyses are ROI-based MVPA and individual-subject ROI definitions using a localizer. The provided full text does not report any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or tables of coordinates clearly identified as a healthy-group whole-brain result. Inclusion requires at least one group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map; that criterion is not met in the supplied content. If the paper’s figures or supplementary materials (not provided here) contain an unmasked group-level whole-brain map for a task contrast, this decision should be revisited.

This is an fMRI task study in healthy adults addressing perception/understanding of self vs. others (own vs. others’ body parts), a social-related construct. Participants are healthy adults and results for the healthy group are reported. The paper reports group-level voxelwise contrasts used to localize ROIs (e.g., body minus objects, objects minus body) with Talairach coordinates and cluster voxel counts, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked results reported via coordinates. Although ROI analyses are also conducted, whole-brain group contrasts are explicitly described. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria for task-based whole-brain fMRI evidence in healthy adults relevant to social processing.

This study reports task-based fMRI of emotional prosody, which is a social-communication/social-perception task relevant to the review. It includes a healthy adult control group (behavioral: n=22, fMRI: n=21; age ranges 20–46), within the 18–65 criterion. The paper presents group-level whole-brain task activation results for controls (emotional vs neutral prosody, complexity and condition contrasts), including conjunction maps and FWE cluster-corrected whole-brain analyses reported in the text/figures, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. Although a clinical ASD group is included, healthy-group results are reported separately. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and reports unmasked healthy-group whole-brain task effects). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (approachability and intelligence judgements from faces) in healthy adults (n=47; ages mean ~32, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task activation contrasts (social vs gender) for the healthy control group, with coordinates, statistical thresholds, figures, and cluster-corrected results. A clinical ASD group is also included but healthy-control results are reported separately. Analyses are not limited to ROI-only, nor to resting-state or connectivity-only methods. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Does not meet the key content inclusion criterion: the fMRI task is a monetary-incentive sustained attention (continuous performance) task, not a social-related task (e.g., social communication, perception/understanding of self or others, affiliation/attachment). Although the paper includes a healthy adult control group (ages 20–50) and reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps for controls, the experimental paradigm does not probe social processing. The presence of clinical participants and correlations with social-interaction symptom scores does not convert a non-social task into a social-task fMRI study. Therefore it fails the requirement that the study uses fMRI during a social-related task.

This is a task-based fMRI study in a sample of healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24) investigating mirror-system responses to action observation/execution and trained geometric shapes — a construct relevant to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ (social cognition). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain analyses (threshold p<0.001 uncorrected, cluster extent 4 voxels) in addition to ROI analyses, and provides peak coordinates and SPMs for task contrasts (Session 1 and Session 2). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, non-task, or clinical-only sample) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (second-language communicative speech) in healthy adult participants (30 native Japanese L2 English learners). The study manipulates communicative vs. descriptive speech and L1 vs. L2 and reports group-level task-evoked activations (e.g., left posterior supramarginal gyrus, left MTG, OFC/insula) tied to L2 communication, indicating whole-brain voxelwise task effects. Participants are within adult age range and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper is empirical and reports task-based whole-brain activations rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based fMRI of social-related processing — participants performed a biological-motion perception task (social perception of others). (2) Sample: healthy adult participants (n=26 analyzed), age range 18–39 (within 18–65). (3) Whole-brain, group-level task results are reported: authors conducted whole-brain analyses of biological-motion selectivity with social-network measures and report a significant cluster in right pSTS/TPJ after correction for multiple comparisons (Monte Carlo simulation, voxel-wise p < .01, cluster-wise corrected p < .05). Results pertain to the healthy/control group (single healthy sample) and are described in the main text (supplemental figure referenced). No exclusion criteria are triggered (not limited to ROIs only, not resting-state/seed-only, not a non-empirical paper). Therefore include.

Although the study includes an fMRI experiment using social phobia-related word stimuli, the fMRI sample consists only of a patient subsample (N=25 female patients with SAD) and the reported imaging analyses focus on patients. No group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map for a healthy/control group is reported separately. Furthermore, the imaging results are reported using an amygdala region-of-interest analysis rather than an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group activation map. Therefore the paper does not meet the review’s requirements for a healthy adult whole-brain task activation and fails the inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (linking person perception and person knowledge) using a task manipulating social agent (body vs name) and social knowledge (trait vs neutral). Sample comprises healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (main effects and interaction) thresholded and described in text and figures, with coordinates and cluster results referenced (including FWE-corrected clusters). Analyses include univariate whole-brain GLM results and connectivity (PPI), not limited to ROI-only or resting-state analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of self- and other-referential processing (social cognition: perception/understanding of self vs others) in healthy adult participants (20 women, ages 18–52). The paper reports task-evoked, group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses and contrasts (e.g., S-N > fixation, S-P > fixation, S-N > S-P, S-N > O-N, S-P > O-P) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster loci/coordinates described in tables and figures. Results are reported for the healthy sample (no clinical-only reporting). The study therefore satisfies: (1) functional MRI during a social-related task, (2) healthy adult sample within 18–65, and (3) whole-brain group-level task activation maps clearly reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-healthy-only reporting) are violated. Hence include.

This is an fMRI study of self-referential (social) processing in healthy adults (n=18, ages 19–29). The task explicitly probes perception/understanding of self vs. other during episodic retrieval. Group-level voxelwise analyses are reported, including whole-brain results (old>new, episodic tasks>control) with coordinates and whole-brain FWE-corrected clusters, in addition to ROI/SVC results for mPFC. The paper is empirical, not connectivity- or ROI-only, and reports healthy-group task activation maps clearly. Participants are within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This fMRI study investigates social-related processing (perception of fearful faces with direct vs. averted gaze) and includes a separate healthy adult control group (n=22, mean age 23.7 yrs, within 18–65). The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise group-level task-evoked analyses for the control group (e.g., within-group AVERTED>DIRECT and AVERTED>FIXATION contrasts), using mixed-effects FLAME and permutation testing with FWE correction and cluster thresholds; results for controls are described in the text and shown as statistical maps. The study therefore meets all inclusion criteria (social task, healthy adult group reported separately, and whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps). It does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, includes suitable age range).

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attentional orienting to social gaze vs. arrow cues; social communication/perception constructs). Sample: 22 healthy adult participants (mean age ~23), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (2×2×2 factorial ANOVA) with voxelwise thresholds and peak coordinates; whole-brain results (incongruent>congruent, invalid>valid, cue contrasts) are described and reported, with additional small-volume corrections—i.e., not ROI-only. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain task fMRI of social processing.

This is an fMRI study that directly examines social-related processing using an altruism (dictator-style) task probing consideration of others’ payoffs and fairness (perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy adults (altruism N=55, subset N=37 also did the food task), ages within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (searchlight SVR maps, SPM second-level tests, conjunctions, and reported cluster coordinates) clearly identified as healthy/control group results; whole-brain results and statistical maps are available on OSF. No clinical groups confound the reported healthy-group maps, and the study is empirical with original fMRI data. It therefore meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (final N=23, mean age 26.4) that examines social perception (animacy, action observation, theory-of-mind related processes) during a task. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (main effects of agent form and belief, interactions) with voxelwise thresholding (p<0.005, cluster reported) and tables/figures of peak coordinates and activations. All inclusion criteria are satisfied (fMRI task in healthy adults; whole-brain group-level results clearly reported). No exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: fMRI task explicitly probes social processing (direct vs averted gaze; social cognition/action control). Sample comprises healthy adults (n=30, ages 19–41). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation maps and contrasts (e.g., incongruent vs congruent; direct vs averted gaze) with cluster- and FWE-thresholding and coordinates described, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirement. Although psychophysiological interaction (PPI) connectivity is reported, this is supplementary to whole-brain task results (not the sole analysis). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED in the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social-related auditory perception (distinguishing one vs two walkers; mentalizing/ social inference). Participants were healthy adults (n=12, ages 22–37). Analysis used group-level random-effects GLM whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST; STEP1 – NOISE1; STEP2 – NOISE2) with reported statistical maps, figures, and Talairach coordinate tables. The paper reports unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation results for the healthy sample (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only). Thus it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Full text provided contains only the References section and bibliographic metadata; no methods, participant characteristics, or results are reported here. I cannot verify that the study (1) used fMRI task data in healthy adult participants (age 18–65), or (2) reported a group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group. The title suggests face/gaze processing and mentions ‘coupling’ (connectivity), which raises the possibility of connectivity analyses without whole-brain task maps, but this cannot be confirmed from the supplied content. Because at least one inclusion criterion (clear reporting of healthy adult whole-brain task activation results) cannot be confirmed, the study must be excluded.

The study reports task-based fMRI of prosodic (social-communication) speech processing, which falls under social-related processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=8, mean age 23.05) within the 18–65 range and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task results for controls (one-sample t-tests, conjunctions, and deactivation maps with thresholding and anatomical localization). Results are not limited to ROIs or connectivity-only analyses. Although sample size is small, all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is a task-based fMRI study of empathy-for-pain, a social-related construct (perception/understanding of others). The sample includes a healthy adult control group (n=18 males, ages 22–63) reported separately alongside an ASD group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (see whole-brain analyses and Supplementary Table 1; contrasts of High Pain–Low Pain in Other, masked by Self, with reported coordinates and between-group whole-brain contrasts). Results for the control/healthy group and subgroup contrasts are clearly described. The study is empirical, uses task-evoked BOLD activation, and does not rely solely on ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task-based functional MRI investigating social-related visual processing (sensitivity to socially relevant spatial relations between bodies: facing vs nonfacing). (2) Sample includes healthy adult participants (fMRI n=20, mean age 24.1), within 18–65. (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., dyads > single-bodies; facing > nonfacing dyads) with tables/figures and cluster-level inference. Not excluded by any criterion: includes whole-brain results (not ROI-only), is empirical fMRI task work in healthy adults, and does not report only connectivity or between-group contrasts. Therefore eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants imagined encountering neutral faces in goal-relevant vs. goal-irrelevant social situations. Sample: healthy adults (n=17; ages 20–36) within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (encoding and recognition ANOVAs), with cluster-corrected voxelwise results and tables/figures of coordinates; some contrasts used small-volume correction but whole-brain results are clearly reported. Design is task-based, not ROI-only or resting-state, and results for the healthy group are presented. No exclusion criteria are violated. Note: sample size is relatively small, but that does not prevent inclusion for this review objective.

While the study uses fMRI to investigate action recognition (a social-cognition-related process) in presumably healthy participants, the full-text excerpt does not explicitly report a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map or give coordinates/tables that would confirm whole-brain results. The summary describes decreased activity in named regions (pSTS, MT/MST, EBA) but does not clarify whether findings derive from whole-brain voxelwise analyses versus ROI-based analyses, nor does it specify participant ages to confirm inclusion in the 18–65 range. Because the inclusion criteria require a clearly identified healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (or equivalent coordinates/figures) and explicit reporting of healthy adult participants, and these elements are not clearly present in the provided text, the study must be excluded.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI of social cognition (trustworthiness judgments) and includes a healthy adult control group (ages 18–35), the reported analyses are limited to a priori ROI extractions and ROI-based statistics and correlations. The paper does not present or describe any group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical maps or tables of whole-brain coordinates for the healthy/control group (results are reported as ROI percent signal change and ROI ANOVAs). Because the review requires at least one unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task activation map or equivalent voxelwise results, this study does not meet the whole-brain evidence inclusion criterion and must be excluded.

The study uses fMRI during social-related tasks (action observation/understanding; theory-of-mind measures) and includes a healthy control (HC) group. However, the full text describes primarily between-group contrasts (ALS > HC, HC > ALS), conjunction analyses, and ROI/small-volume results. The paper does not clearly report an unmasked, whole-brain, group-level task activation map or main-effect/within-group contrast explicitly identified as coming from the healthy/control group (i.e., a standalone HC whole-brain activation map reported in text/tables). Because the review requires at least one clearly described healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked statistical map, this criterion is not met. Therefore the study must be excluded.

This is a task-based fMRI study of face-to-face social interaction (eye contact) using dyadic fMRI in healthy adults (38 participants, ages 18–33 reported; healthy university sample). The paper reports group-level whole-brain GLM results and paired t-tests, thresholded maps (Z>2.3, p<0.05 and cluster information), cluster coordinates in MNI space, and probabilistic atlas labels — satisfying the requirement for voxelwise, whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group. It is not an ROI-only, resting-state, or connectivity-only paper, and healthy-group results are reported separately. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (self- and other-reflection). It includes a separate healthy adult control group (n=33) within the 18–65 age range and reports group-level, whole-brain task activation contrasts for the control group (e.g., Self>Facts, Other>Facts, Other>Self) with voxelwise cluster-level inference (z-threshold and cluster-correction) and coordinate tables/figures. Although a clinical (schizophrenia) group is also included, healthy-group results are reported separately. The study does not limit results to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social communication in healthy adults (54 right-handed males, ages 18–27). The task explicitly probes Social Communication and mutual understanding. The paper reports group-level whole-brain analyses (cluster-level corrected; contrasts and coordinates described, rSTG findings and whole-brain search), not limited to ROI or connectivity-only results. Healthy adult group results are reported separately and meet the age criterion. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Although this fMRI study tests self-related processing in healthy adult participants (ages 18–35) using a task probing perception/understanding of self, the reported neuroimaging results are based on ROI / small-volume analyses. The manuscript does not clearly present a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked activation map for the healthy sample; reported coordinates and statistics appear to come from restricted ROI/SVC analyses. Therefore it fails the review’s required criterion of documented whole-brain group-level task activation and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (charitable giving probing empathy, perspective taking, attention). Sample: healthy adult participants (n=33, ages 20–34) meeting the 18–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (searchlight MVPA and SVR/SVC results) with FWE-corrected thresholds and tables of significant clusters/coordinates, clearly from the healthy sample. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, nor to between-group contrasts; whole-brain task-evoked maps and coordinates are reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (perception/understanding of others via emotional facial expressions) in a healthy adult sample (final N=25, ages 21–33). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses: univariate whole-brain random-effects contrasts (faces > objects) used to define ROIs, and whole-brain searchlight analyses with SnPM correction (p<.05) and reported clusters/coordinates (Table 3, figures). The task explicitly manipulates social dimensions (emotion vs. age) during fMRI. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-state only, healthy adult group reported separately). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mind perception and gaze-cueing) in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 24). The experiment used task-evoked fMRI during a mind-perception task and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise parametric analyses (family-wise error cluster correction reported), with activation maps and coordinate tables (vmPFC and other social-brain regions) clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. The study is empirical, within the target age range (18–65), and provides whole-brain task activation results rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=31, ages 18–35) that examines neural responses to viewing faces with vs. without facial disfigurement—an instance of social perception/Perception and Understanding of Others. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (contrasts of pre- vs. post-surgery faces) with familywise-error cluster correction and describes significant clusters (fusiform/occipital increases; medial anterior cingulate decreases). The sample is within the 18–65 range and results are reported for the healthy group (no clinical subgroup-only reporting). The analysis is whole-brain (not ROI-only or connectivity-only). Thus all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social perception (perception/understanding of others via facial expressions) in healthy adult participants (n=24, mean age 25.2). The authors performed first-level and group-level mixed-effects (FLAME) analyses and report group-level parameter estimate maps for each expression condition and a group-level localiser contrast (faces > scrambled faces) used to define face-selective regions; supplementary tables/maps are indicated. Thus the study includes task-evoked, group-level whole-brain statistical maps from a healthy adult sample and is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social scenarios (counterfactual emotions after risky decisions), which falls under social-related processing (perception/understanding of others/self in social context). The sample includes a healthy young adult group (30 young adults; adults within 18–65) reported separately from late adolescents. The abstract reports voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked activations (e.g., orbitofrontal cortex, MTG, posterior cingulate, precuneus, insula, IFG, pre-SMA, caudate, STS) for the age groups and contrasts (regret vs. disappointment, etc.), indicating whole-brain group-level results rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only; includes healthy adults; provides whole-brain task activations). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This fMRI study tested social processing (social distance trials using participants' friends vs acquaintances; names and photographs) in a task context relevant to perception/understanding of others. Sample: healthy adults (n=15, ages 20–28), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain searchlight MVPA and RSA analyses with statistical maps aligned to standard space and thresholded across participants (conjunction analyses, FDR-corrected clusters reported in tables/figures), which constitute voxelwise task-evoked, whole-brain results from the healthy group. Analyses are not ROI-only, nor are they resting-state or connectivity-only. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult subjects (N=12) that investigates processing of emotional facial expressions — a social-communication/social-perception task relevant to the review objective. The abstract reports BOLD signal increases across multiple brain regions for implicit and explicit conditions and direct comparisons, indicating group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation results (not limited to ROIs). No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adults). Age range is not explicitly reported but participants are described as healthy subjects (adult sample). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain fMRI evidence in healthy adults, with minor uncertainty due to lack of explicit ages reported.

Although this is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants addressing social-related audiovisual non-verbal face processing and reports group-level, voxelwise activation contrasts, the functional acquisition used a split-sagittal, limited-slice coverage that explicitly excluded medial regions and other parts of the brain. The review’s inclusion criterion requires at least one group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (i.e., whole-brain coverage). Because the reported voxelwise analyses are based on partial-brain coverage rather than whole-brain imaging, the study does not meet the ’whole-brain evidence’ requirement and must be excluded.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (fMRI sample n=29, mean age 25.6) investigating social-related processing (learning about others’ inter-temporal preferences, social influence, perception/understanding of others). The task required evaluating choices for self and others during fMRI and interleaved probe trials. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and cluster-level FWE-corrected results (including coordinates and whole-brain contrasts testing repetition suppression and surprise signals in mPFC, striatum, pMFC), not limited to ROI-only analyses. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion requirements for the review.

The study used task-based fMRI (event-related fMRI) during perception of others’ emotional facial expressions, a social cognitive task (perception/understanding of others/empathy). The sample comprises 14 healthy adult volunteers (mean age 29±6), within the 18–65 range. The abstract reports statistical parametric mapping results identifying activation in dorsal medial frontal cortex (pre-SMA) during emotion perception, indicating group-level, voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked analyses rather than ROI-only results. No exclusion criteria apply (not connectivity-only, not patient-only, and not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult whole-brain fMRI studies of social processing.

This is an fMRI study of healthy adults using social tasks (theory-of-mind; social attribution-of-attention) and participants are within the 18–65 range. However, the primary task analyses are performed using localized ICA restricted to a TPJ-region-of-interest and mixed-effects regression on IC time courses. The paper does not report an unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map (GLM main effect or within-group contrast) for the healthy group. Although seed-to-voxel functional connectivity maps (whole-brain) are reported, these are connectivity results rather than task-evoked whole-brain activation maps. Because the study lacks the required whole-brain task-evoked healthy-group map, it fails the inclusion criteria and should be excluded.

This fMRI study includes a healthy adult group (N=12; ages 22.6–30.4) within the 18–65 range, uses task-based fMRI of social-related processing (direct and reflected self-appraisals: perception/understanding of self and others), and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses and contrasts for the adults (e.g., one-sample t tests, conjunctions, and ANOVAs with whole-brain correction and reported coordinates/clusters). Results for the healthy adult group are presented separately and are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/rest analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Although this fMRI study reports whole-brain, group-level task contrasts for healthy adult participants, the task does not target social-related processing as defined by the review (affiliation/attachment, social communication, perception/understanding of self or others). The paradigms present erotic pictures and videos to probe sexual arousal and orientation (ventral striatum reward/incentive responses). While some brain regions related to perception or mentalizing are reported incidentally, the primary experimental manipulation and aims are sexual incentive/orientation, not social cognition. Therefore it fails the requirement that the study use fMRI during a social-related task and should be excluded.

This study reports task fMRI in healthy adult samples (HCP: n≈93–97 per task, ages 22–36+; UCLA stop-signal: n=114, ages 21–50), all within the 18–65 range. It includes a social cognition task (social interaction vs. random movement) which clearly targets perception/understanding of others. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation analyses (voxel-wise GLMs and figures showing ROI-wise/voxelwise activations; Figure 1 and Supplementary materials), with effects described for the healthy/control participants. Although the paper emphasizes connectivity (PPI/BSC), it explicitly reports whole-brain activation maps and group-level contrasts for the healthy samples. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task activations) and does not violate exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (social exclusion/Cyberball) in healthy adult participants (final N=20, ages ~25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play collapsed across gender; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with voxelwise results, cluster-correction, coordinate tables, and figures. Although ROI analyses are also presented, whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy adult group are clearly reported. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (cooperation/competition; self–other judgments) in healthy adults (final sample N=24, age 19–31). The paper reports group-level, task-evoked whole-brain voxelwise analyses (GLM whole-brain results identifying pgACC and area 9 and related effects) rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only findings. No clinical/special-group results are required and the healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task is a social-related fMRI task (subjects judged another’s awareness—perception/understanding of others). (2) Sample includes healthy adult participants (group of 50 healthy adults, ages 18–49; fMRI group results are reported for this healthy group). (3) Whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation maps/contrasts are reported (H trials − E trials contrast across all 50 subjects, thresholded P<0.05 corrected; Talairach coordinates provided in Table 1 and figures). Study is empirical and not ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only. Therefore it qualifies for inclusion in the meta-analysis of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

While this is an fMRI study of social-emotional face processing in healthy adult males (meets task and sample criteria), the imaging acquisition used a restricted slab (10 oblique slices centered on the amygdala) and the authors explicitly note limited coverage. Although they report voxelwise "whole-slab" results and ROI analyses, they do not report a group-level, whole-brain (full brain coverage) voxelwise task activation map for the healthy group. The review’s inclusion criterion requires whole-brain group-level maps; absence of whole-brain coverage/whole-brain results therefore excludes this study.

The study is an empirical fMRI investigation of social cognition in healthy adult participants (Princeton undergraduates, mean age 19.5). It uses task-based fMRI during social-affective judgments (SCM emotions) and reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise contrasts and Talairach coordinates (e.g., mPFC, insula, amygdala activations, t-values, voxel counts). Results are reported for the healthy control/participant group (not limited to an ROI-only analysis), and the paper presents unmasked whole-brain task-evoked effects. No exclusion criteria apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of maternal social/attachment processing (listening to own infant’s cry), which fits the social-related task domain (Affiliation/Attachment). Participants are healthy adults (mothers; mean age 24.1 years, within 18–65); although some had prior perinatal MDE or current SSRI use, none met criteria for a major depressive episode at the time of scanning and depressive symptom effects were tested/controlled. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (own cry > control/other contrasts) with cluster-level results and MNI coordinates (Table 1) using whole-brain FDR correction. Thus it provides the required whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. Caveat: sample is a convenience/high-risk motherhood sample (includes past perinatal depression history and 3 medicated participants) and analyses are from the combined sample rather than a separate “healthy-only” subgroup, but the reported group-level whole-brain results meet inclusion criteria.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social-related processing (moral dilemma/kinship and a moral-decision task). Participants: healthy adult sample (N=30; females aged 19–39), meeting the 18–65 requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses: inter-subject correlation (ISC) maps across the whole brain with FDR correction and cluster reporting, and a separate GLM whole-brain analysis of the moral-dilemma decision task (group-level contrasts, corrected, with tables of clusters/coordinates and neurovault link). Results are reported for the healthy sample (no mixed clinical groups). The study is neither ROI-only nor resting-state/connectivity-only and provides unmasked whole-brain task effects for the healthy group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

Although the study uses task fMRI probing personal familiarity (a social-cognition construct) and reports whole-brain, within-group activation maps for the healthy control group, the control participants are elderly (older adults) rather than healthy adults aged 18–65. No healthy adult subgroup in the 18–65 age range is reported separately. This violates the sample age inclusion criterion (studies must include a healthy adult group age 18–65 or report such a subgroup), therefore the study must be excluded from the meta-analysis.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=19, ages 18–51) that investigates emotional prosody comprehension, a social-cognition process (perception/understanding of others’ emotions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise statistical contrasts (emotional vs neutral; complex vs simple emotions) analyzed with SPM8 and corrected for multiple comparisons, with coordinates and activation maps described. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or resting-state analyses, and the healthy adult group results are reported directly. All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This study used task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=8, ages 22–39) where natural interpersonal touch (another person touching the subject) was the experimental manipulation — a social-related stimulus relevant to social perception/communication. The authors report group-level whole-brain voxelwise spatial maps derived from group ICA (thresholded z-maps) that identify task-related components in the primary somatosensory cortex and wider networks, and they present corresponding group-level statistical comparisons of component time courses. The paper is not ROI-only, not purely resting-state/seed-connectivity, and the whole-brain task-related maps are clearly from the healthy/control sample. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (anticipation of touching an animate vs inanimate target). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=32, ages 21–33; task data in 21 participants but healthy adult group reported). The paper presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (paired-sample t-test: anticipation animate vs inanimate; whole-brain analyses with PNI covariates) with FDR-corrected statistical maps and reported coordinates/clusters. Although additional resting-state analyses (PLE, DFA) are included, the study provides unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task activation results rather than only ROI or connectivity analyses. Age range and healthy-group reporting meet inclusion criteria. Therefore it qualifies for inclusion.

This is an fMRI task study of social perception (perception/understanding of others via body motion and potential for social involvement) in healthy adults (N=16, mean age 22.8). The paper reports group-level task contrasts (main effects and interactions) and provides stereotaxic coordinates of BOLD peaks and statistical details in the text/tables from the healthy group. Although analyses focus on mirror-neuron and mentalizing masks, contrasts were computed at the second level and results are reported voxelwise (coordinate tables and thresholded statistical maps within masks), satisfying the requirement for group-level voxelwise task-evoked results from healthy participants. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical, outside age range) apply. Therefore the study meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria as an fMRI task activation study of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an event-related fMRI task study of facial gender perception — a form of social perception (perception/understanding of others). Sample: healthy adults aged 19–42 (N=16 recruited, N=15 analyzed), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxel-wise analyses (gender-different > gender-same) with cluster-corrected thresholds and lists activated clusters/coordinates (right collateral sulcus, left precuneus, right lateral occipital gyrus, etc.). Thus it provides healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, not non-empirical). Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

The study reports task-based fMRI targeting dynamic facial expression processing (social perception of others) and uses a dynamic face-expression localizer contrast (dynamic facial expressions > static neutral faces + moving dots), which is a social-related task. The paper explicitly states the localizer successfully identified a pSTS cluster across subjects and uses group-level random-effects analyses (RFX), indicating whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts rather than only ROI or connectivity results. Participants are typical subjects (healthy adult sample used for neurofeedback), and results are reported for the healthy group. The study therefore meets: (1) social-related fMRI task, (2) healthy adult sample, and (3) whole-brain group-level task activation map reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical) apply. Consequently, it should be included for the review.

While the study is an fMRI investigation of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (N=36) using an appropriate social task, the reported neuroimaging results are confined to a priori small-volume–corrected analyses within a bilateral vACC ROI. The manuscript describes group-level analyses and ROI-based SVC results but does not present or describe an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-activation map for the healthy group (nor whole-brain coordinates/tables) that would meet the review’s whole-brain evidence requirement. Therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked map for healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of empathy for pain (a social-cognitive task) in healthy adult participants (n=67 analyzed; ages 18–40). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (e.g., STRESS>CONTROL contrasts for INJECTION>QTIP and BIOPSY>QTIP) with whole-brain FWE correction and MNI coordinates, clearly described in the text and supplementary material. Although many reported contrasts are between two healthy groups (stress vs control), both groups consist of healthy adults and the analyses are group-level, voxelwise, whole-brain statistical maps suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis of social processing in healthy adults. Therefore the study meets the inclusion criteria (fMRI social task; healthy adult sample; whole-brain group-level voxelwise results).

This is an fMRI study of social evaluation (social cognition/perception) in healthy adults (N=20, ages 18–29). The task is a social judgment task (forced-choice evaluations of target persons) and analyses report group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (multilevel whole-brain MLM, reported clusters with MNI coordinates, DLPFC and dACC activations). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain effects are clearly described. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study’s sample consists of youth aged 8–19 and reports developmental analyses across that adolescent range. Although whole-brain task fMRI and DTI results are reported, there is no distinct group of healthy adults (age 18–65) analyzed or reported separately. Age is treated continuously within an adolescent sample and adult comparisons are not provided. Therefore the study does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group (18–65) with a clear whole-brain task-evoked map. Exclude on participant/sample grounds.

Although the study uses task-based fMRI and reports group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) results (FWE-corrected) relevant to social processing, the participant sample is adolescent/young adults with ages ranging 17–20 (mean 18). The paper does not report a separate healthy adult (age 18–65) subgroup analyzed independently; the sample is treated as an adolescent/young adult group and authors note limited generalizability to adults. Because the inclusion criterion requires at least one group of healthy adult participants (18–65) reported separately or clearly meeting the age range, this study fails the sample-age criterion and must be excluded despite meeting the imaging and task criteria.

This study reports fMRI during a social task (facial emotion recognition) in healthy adults (n=14 controls, ages within 18–65) and provides whole-brain, group-level within-group contrasts for the healthy control group (e.g., NTOXT>PLA whole-brain results with reported clusters and coordinates in the text/Table 2). The paper also reports task design, preprocessing, and exploratory whole-brain analyses (uncorrected p<0.001, k>10) and separate results for the healthy group, meeting the requirement for a healthy-group, voxelwise task-evoked map. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Task: event/state sentence reading including numerous sentences describing social interactions; authors explicitly identify a ‘people and social interactions’ semantic factor and report associated brain regions. This constitutes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others/social interactions). (2) Sample: seven healthy adult participants (ages 20–35), satisfying the 18–65 healthy adult requirement. (3) Whole-brain evidence: authors performed whole-brain fMRI, report group-level analyses (group-averaged images, factor analysis-derived voxel clusters and brain locations; Figure 4A and Supporting Information Table S3 provide voxel/cluster mappings), i.e., group-level, voxelwise task-evoked results for the healthy sample. (4) Not excluded: results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient groups; this is original task-based fMRI data in healthy adults. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED in the review of social-related fMRI processing in healthy adults.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social cognition (naturalistic theory-of-mind/mentalising task). A healthy control group (controls: n=22; fMRI subset n=20; ages 19–46) is reported separately from the autism group. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level within-group task contrast (ToM > physical inference) for the control group with cluster-corrected voxelwise results (tables and figures of activations), satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The study is not ROI-only, not resting-state/seed-only, and participants fall in the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI task study of face perception (passive face/object/texture viewing), which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=51, ages 18–42) reported separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts for the adult/control group (e.g., Face>Object, Face>Fixation; FLAME mixed-effects group analyses with cluster correction) presented in figures and tables. The study is empirical, not connectivity-only, and provides unmasked whole-brain activation results for the healthy adults. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social cognition (monitoring another’s decisions) in healthy adults (n=12, mean age 21). The experiment reports group-level, random-effects voxelwise analyses (SPM ANOVA) with reported coordinates and figures for task-evoked effects in the ACC, and these results are clearly from the healthy/control group. Although small-volume correction (ACC mask) was applied for multiple-comparisons, whole-brain voxelwise analyses and group-level contrasts were performed and reported (coordinates and SPM results), satisfying the whole-brain evidence criterion. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not resting-state, participants within 18–65). Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (dynamic facial-expression perception) in healthy adult participants (ages ~22, N=18 for fMRI), meeting the sample criterion. The authors performed voxelwise second-level group analyses in SPM (ANOVA) and report group-level task-evoked activation peaks with stereotaxic coordinates and statistical parametric maps (conjunctions and interaction contrasts), not limited to connectivity or patient-vs-control contrasts. Although many reported effects were assessed with ROI masks / small-volume correction, group-level voxelwise task contrasts and coordinates are provided for healthy adults. No exclusion criteria are met (not resting-state, not only ROI/seed connectivity, and participants are within 18–65). Therefore the paper qualifies for inclusion.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=18, ages 19–36) using a face memory/recognition task — a social cognition paradigm (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (false recognition vs. recognition/correct rejection) with Random Effects analysis, cluster correction, and Talairach coordinates for activated regions (right precentral and cingulate gyri). Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses, and participants fall within the 18–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (masked fearful vs happy eye whites) in healthy adults (male participants, mean age ~24). The study reports group-level task-evoked analyses and explicitly conducted exploratory whole-brain analyses (reported clusters in right pulvinar, ACC, orbitofrontal cortex, Supplementary Tables S1–S3) in the healthy/placebo and oxytocin groups. Whole-brain, voxelwise results with coordinates and cluster sizes are presented and described for the healthy groups, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. The design and sample fall within the inclusion age range (18–65). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy sample) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in a sample of healthy adult participants (N=74) using a social-related task (neutral face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM). The manuscript reports group-level whole-brain task activation analyses (one-sample t-tests and contrasts) with FWE-corrected thresholds and presents whole-brain results (figures and supplementary tables). While ROI and connectivity analyses are also reported, whole-brain healthy-group task effects are clearly described and meet the review’s requirement for unmasked, within-group activation maps. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, and healthy adults are analyzed separately). Age range is not explicitly stated in the excerpt, but participants are described as healthy adults; there is no indication they fall outside 18–65. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants viewed dyadic violent interactions (social perception of others/affiliation/emotion). Sample: healthy adult participants (N=15 males; mean age 23.6), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked results (e.g., all conditions vs baseline, and focus-on-aggressor vs focus-on-victim contrasts) with statistical thresholds and cluster correction (p-values, FDR/Monte Carlo), and describes activation and coordinate-based findings across multiple brain regions. Although sample is modest and predominantly male, results for the healthy group are reported directly. The study therefore satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, reports healthy-group whole-brain activations).

This is a task-based fMRI study of social processing (empathy/mentalising) in healthy adults (final sample n=34, ages 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., emotional > neutral) and voxelwise correlations (EA modulation, time-series correlations with intensity), analyzed with SPM12/FSL and TFCE FWE correction, with peak activations and cluster tables. It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and healthy-group whole-brain results are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are violated.

The healthy sample comprises adolescent males (age range 13–19); no healthy adult (18–65) subgroup is reported separately. Thus the study fails the sample inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group. Although the study used task fMRI and reports whole-brain analyses (exploratory across groups), it does not clearly present an unmasked, whole-brain task activation map for the healthy adult group. Therefore it does not meet the review’s age-based inclusion criterion (and likely the healthy-group whole-brain reporting requirement).

This is an fMRI task study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: attribution of intentions, deception vs cooperation) in healthy adult participants (n=13, ages 22–38). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses (exploratory whole-brain ToM vs non-ToM contrast with reported cluster peaks and coordinates) and subsequent contrasts between task conditions. Results for the healthy group are reported clearly (coordinates, contrasts, figures/tables). It is not ROI-only, not connectivity- or resting-state-only, and participants fall within the 18–65 range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (imitate/observe emotional faces) in healthy adults (initial N=28; final imaging N=20; ages 18–55). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses: a task PLS and a GLM in SPM8 with voxelwise maps and bootstrap-thresholded voxel patterns (rendered on the brain and described in the text). Results are reported for the healthy/control sample (no patient-only or ROI-only restrictions). The methods and results clearly present whole-brain, voxelwise task activation patterns related to social cognitive processing, satisfying all inclusion criteria and violating none of the exclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI task probing social perception of others (dynamic pupillary signals), which maps to ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’. Sample: 14 healthy adult participants (mean age 22), meeting the age and healthy-sample requirement. Group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (main effect of viewing eyes reported at whole-brain corrected cluster threshold p<.05; second-level analyses of pupil-change effects and interactions reported with voxelwise thresholds and coordinate tables), so whole-brain task-evoked maps from the healthy group are available. The paper is empirical, not resting-state/seed-only, and reports task activation (not limited to ROI-only results). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

The study uses task fMRI with healthy adult controls and addresses social-related processing (emotion word comprehension). However, the paper does not clearly report an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group alone. Key whole-brain results are presented either pooled across all participants or as between-group (control > ASC) contrasts, and ROI analyses and within-group ROI statistics for controls are reported, but a clearly identified whole-brain healthy-group task effect (main effect or within-group voxelwise map) is not provided in the full text. Because the review requires at least one clearly reported healthy-group whole-brain task map, this study fails that criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (college students, ages 19–24) that uses a social-related task (self-face recognition — perception/understanding of self). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and random-effects analyses (e.g., Morph 50% self vs friend; reported MPFC, PCC, precuneus clusters with MNI coordinates and corrected cluster-level thresholds), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. The sample and results for the healthy group are reported separately. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity/resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports an fMRI experiment using a social-interaction task (virtual handshake; social rejection vs acceptance), addressing social processing constructs (mentalizing, perception of others). It includes a healthy adult control group (n=16, mean age 27.4) reported separately. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain within-group contrasts for the control group (refusal > acceptance: right pSTS and thalamus) with statistical thresholds and cluster correction described. It is not limited to ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Participants’ ages and sample meet the 18–65 range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI probing social-related face perception/emotional/mentalizing processes (Thatcher Illusion, attention to eyes/mouth). (2) Includes a healthy adult control group (neurotypical adults, mean age ~25.8) with results reported separately. (3) Reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise within-group task contrasts for the healthy/control group (statistical maps and thresholds described for NT). No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state-only, healthy adults within 18–65). Therefore it should be included.

This fMRI study examines social perception (gaze processing/theory-of-mind), using a task involving direct vs. averted gaze. It includes a healthy adult control group (initial n=25; adults) with group-level, within-group contrasts reported (controls: direct > averted gaze) derived from a second-level voxelwise GLM. Coordinates and P-values for group and within-group contrasts are presented (tables/figures), and voxelwise results are described (visualized at P<0.001 uncorrected and small-volume corrected ROIs). Although some ROI-based small-volume correction was used, the paper reports group-level, voxelwise task-evoked activation for the healthy/control group separately, meeting the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria (e.g., only ROI-only analyses, only connectivity/resting-state, or no healthy adult data) apply. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

Although the study uses fMRI during a social task (empathy/sympathy) and reports group-level whole-brain activation maps, the sample is mixed-age (N=57, ages 7–40) and the authors do not report a separate healthy adult (18–65) group-level whole-brain task effect. Results are presented for the combined sample and age-correlations rather than an adult-only group. Because the meta-analysis requires at least one clearly reported healthy adult (18–65) group-level whole-brain task map (or a healthy adult subgroup analyzed/reported separately), this paper does not meet the sample criterion and must be excluded.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult males (ages 18–35) using a social provocation task (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) that probes social-related processing (response to others, anger, social decision-making). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (high>low provocation; decision and feedback phases) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction, clearly from the healthy/control sample (n=93 after exclusions). It is not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses and participants fall within the 18–65 age range. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody) in healthy adult participants (n=22, mean age 27), satisfying the sample criterion (ages within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, task-evoked voxelwise contrasts (CLEAR>AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS>CLEAR) with statistical thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and presents activation maps and coordinates; thus whole-brain evidence is available. The study is not limited to ROI-only or resting-state/connectivity-only analyses (PPI is included but additional whole-brain activation maps are reported). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study uses task-based fMRI (Cyberball social exclusion) addressing social-related processing. It includes a healthy adult control group (HC; n=28) reported separately. The paper presents whole-brain, group-level task-evoked results for the healthy controls (main effect of condition: left anterior insula/inferior frontal gyrus) with voxelwise FWE correction and reported coordinates/figures. The task contrasts (ESE vs INC, ISE vs INC) and statistical maps are clearly described for HC. Not ROI-only, not resting-state or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria.

Meets all inclusion criteria: (1) Uses task-based fMRI during a social-related impression-formation task (perception/understanding of others, varying race and status). (2) Sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=60 males, mean age 23.8). (3) Reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (GLM contrasts used for PLS; whole-brain PLS results with voxelwise bootstrap ratios, cluster reporting, and figures), not limited to ROI or resting-state or seed connectivity. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore include.

Meets all inclusion criteria: empirical fMRI study of social processing (self vs other processing in romantic relationships). Sample comprises healthy adults aged 23–40 (within 18–65). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts are reported (e.g., self positive > neutral, other negative > neutral) with one-sample t-tests, ANOVA, and FWE correction; results presented as tables/figures and described in text. Not limited to ROI, resting-state, or connectivity-only analyses. No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study is eligible for inclusion in the meta-analysis of healthy adult fMRI studies of social-related processing.

This is an fMRI task study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (n=27, ages ~24–26). The study used task-evoked BOLD fMRI with event-related design and reports group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise analyses (contrasts, conjunctions, and interaction effects) with FWE-corrected thresholds and figures/tables of activations. Although ROIs were also used, whole-brain results are clearly reported for the healthy participant group. The sample is within the 18–65 age range and results for the healthy group are presented directly. The study does not rely solely on ROI, connectivity, or resting-state analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

Multiple inclusion criteria are not met. Participants are adolescents (age 12–18), not healthy adults aged 18–65, so the sample is outside the required age range. The task is the Embedded Figures Task, a visual search/perceptual task, not a social-related paradigm (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception/understanding of self/others). Although whole-brain group-level fMRI contrasts are reported, they pertain to adolescent case/sibling/control groups and not to a healthy adult group. Therefore the study does not provide a whole-brain task activation map from healthy adults and does not address social processing in adults.

While the study uses task fMRI of social processing (emotional face perception) and includes healthy adult participants (and an independent healthy replication sample), it does not report a group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. The primary whole-brain analyses were conducted on a combined sample (patients + controls) and the independent healthy replication used an anatomical ROI approach (fusiform ROI) rather than an unmasked whole-brain healthy-group contrast. Therefore it fails the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map and must be excluded.

This study uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (samples aged 18–24). Tasks probe social-related constructs (self-related processing, mentalizing/social cognition) during article exposure. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (exploratory whole-brain searches, thresholded maps, and whole-brain tables/clusters with cluster and nonparametric FDR correction) clearly derived from the healthy participant samples.
